user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of deinit_data:
```c
static void
deinit_data (void)
{
  if (NULL != resp_single)
    MHD_destroy_response (resp_single);
  resp_single = NULL;
  if (NULL != resps)
  {
    unsigned int i;
    for (i = 0; i < num_resps; ++i)
      MHD_destroy_response (resps[i]);
    num_resps = 0;
    free (resps);
  }
  resps = NULL;
  if (NULL != body_dyn)
    free (body_dyn);
  body_dyn = NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function deinit_data:
_MHD_EXTERN void
MHD_destroy_response (struct MHD_Response *response)
{
  struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *pos;

  if (NULL == response)
    return;
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&response->mutex);
#endif
  if (0 != --(response->reference_count))
  {
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
    MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&response->mutex);
#endif
    return;
  }
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&response->mutex);
  MHD_mutex_destroy_chk_ (&response->mutex);
#endif
  if (NULL != response->crfc)
    response->crfc (response->crc_cls);

  if (NULL != response->data_iov)
  {
    free (response->data_iov);
  }

  while (NULL != response->first_header)
  {
    pos = response->first_header;
    response->first_header = pos->next;
    free (pos->header);
    free (pos->value);
    free (pos);
  }
  free (response);
}
...
static struct MHD_Response *resp_single = NULL
...
static struct MHD_Response **resps = NULL
...
static unsigned int num_resps = 0
...
static char *body_dyn = NULL
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no explicit uses of compiler language extensions in the deinit_data function or the shown related symbols: all pointer checks against NULL, calls to free(), the for-loop, assignments, and function-pointer invocation use standard C. The conditional compilation using defined(...) is the standard preprocessor, and the mutex/function calls (MHD_mutex_lock_chk_, MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_, MHD_mutex_destroy_chk_) and other identifiers shown are normal function or macro names as presented and do not themselves prove use of a compiler language extension.

The only fragment that could mask a compiler-specific extension is the _MHD_EXTERN macro at the start of the MHD_destroy_response definition: such linkage/visibility macros are commonly defined to expand to compiler-specific attributes (for example GCC __attribute__ or MSVC __declspec), which are language extensions. Its expansion is not shown here, so that macro occurrence should be investigated to determine whether it expands to any compiler-specific extension. No other code lines in the provided snippets contain explicit extension syntax (e.g., __attribute__, __asm__, typeof, statement expressions, nested functions, or other compiler-specific tokens) and therefore do not require investigation for Rule 1.2 based on the supplied code.
